repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Seeds Systems Development
            Project and National Fertilizer Sector Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Seeds Systems
            Development Project (SSDP) of Ethiopia were as follows:
            outcome was moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was significant; Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory; and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. The ratings for the National Fertilizer
            Sector Project (NFSP) of Ethiopia were as follows: outcome
            was unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was unsatisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was unsatisfactory. The main lessons
            from the experience o f SSDP and NFSP are as follows: 1)
            Strategically oriented sector work is essential as a base
            for a relevant and effective rural development program; 2)
            Better coordination and linkages are needed between projects
            and within the rural sector as a whole; 3) Development of a
            competitive fertilizer market requires actions beyond
            "Market Liberalization"; 4) Reliance on the public
            sector for input supply may create not only market
            inefficiencies but also a shortage of inputs; 5)
            Institutional structures and processes can restrict private
            sector participation; 6) A one-size-fits-all agricultural
            extension system has limited impact; and 7) A
            strategy-focused program requires performance indicators,
            monitoring, and an adaptive approach, reflecting the
            strategic objectives and outcomes relative to these objectives.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            and project sustainability is regarded as likely. World Bank
            performance is evaluated as unsatisfactory, while Borrower
            performance is judged as satisfactory. These were some of
            the lessons learned: 1) Successfully creating a market-based
            seed production and distribution system in place of a
            centrally-based system requires the gradual involvement of
            the private sector. 2) see production should be based on a
            thorough assessment of farmer demand and market for improved
            varieties, not just focusing on supply. 3) Substantial
            changes to the project design should not be made without
            fully analyzing the proposed design in terms of economic,
            financial, and social impacts and ensuring that the new
            approach is sustainable. 4) to ensure better implementation,
            arrangements for monitoring and evaluation need to be in
            place before the project starts. 5) To ensure continuity and
            sustainability, planning and initiating transitional
            arrangements well in advance of project closure (some 18
            months) is necessary. 6) Single factor projects are unlikely
            to have a major impact on agricultural production. 7)
            Government commitment is critical for the timely
            finalization of project preparation. 8) Assess the impact of
            an evolving situation and act quickly: the project failed to
            assess the impact of a rapidly expanding approach which
            relied on a single market outlet under the national
            extension intervention program on the project. It also
            failed to act decisively in response to these changes.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Seed Systems Development Project
            will contribute to the national goal of increased
            agricultural production and productivity by laying the
            foundation for the development of a broad-based and
            competitive seed industry which draws its strength both from
            the formal and the informal seed system. The project
            supports Seed Policy Reform, through each of its two
            components. The components are : (a) Seed Enterprise
            Development; and (b) Capacity Building. The first component
            supports (i) the development of the informal seed sector;
            (ii) encourages private sector entry into the formal
            business; and supports (iii) the restructuring of the
            Ethiopian Seed Enterprise from a centrally managed
            parastatal to a decentralized and commercially oriented
            enterprise. The second component involves: (i) institutional
            strengthening; and (ii) human resource development, both in
            the formal and the informal sector.

The Seed Systems Development Project
            will contribute to the national goal of increased
